items.title: Struggle is Inevitable

items.content_html:
I went back to full-time work after a four-year sabbatical. While it was exciting, I deeply missed being at home with my son. I started second-guessing myself and wondering if I had made the right decision.

Eventually, I found my rhythm again and settled into work. I wrote the words below in my journal a few months ago and completely forgot about themâ€”until I reread them recently. They resonated with me, and I felt called to share them.

If you ever find yourself sitting with similar doubts, I hope this helps you through it.

Struggle is inevitable.

When it shows up again, draw confidence from your past experiences. You have struggled before. You doubted yourselfâ€”yet you overcame those moments and came out stronger and wiser.

Maybe self-doubt is a feeling youâ€™re meant to sit with for a while.

You can listen to it speak. Understand where itâ€™s coming from. Then, gently and respectfully, disagree with it.

You may feel a lack of confidenceâ€”but you can choose to believe something else: that despite how it feels right now, youâ€™ve already proven, time and again, that youâ€™re capable of more than you give yourself credit for.

Maybe these low moments are necessary for growth. They encourage reflection and protect us from the bigger mistakes that can come from unchecked confidence.

Accept that this feeling will visit from time to time. Welcome it. Learn from it. And rememberâ€”it is temporary.

Find the lesson, so you can let it go.

You are not your worst enemyâ€”you are your best challenger. You challenge yourself to keep growing, even when itâ€™s hard. And look how far youâ€™ve already come because of it.

Believe in yourself.

items.title: Rules of Anger

items.content_html:
Mom Guilt

I stopped blogging for a while because I was afraid that maybe I was sharing too much. Most people only show the best parts of their lives online â€” and here I was writing about some of Kyleâ€™s most vulnerable moments.

I felt guilty, wondering if I was making him seem like a difficult or angry child. In truth, he is one of the sweetest boys I know â€” thoughtful, smart, funny, and kind. I shared our struggles not to label him, but in the hope that it might help other parents feel less alone.

As parents, we all have strong opinions about how children should be raised. Itâ€™s easy to judge through our own lens and forget that every child, family, and situation is different. Iâ€™m guilty of this too, and Iâ€™m learning to be more intentional.

I know that sharing pieces of our life opens us up to judgment. But I choose to keep sharing, because we grow when we learn from one another. What matters most isnâ€™t what everyone else thinks â€” itâ€™s what we believe, and how we show up for the people we love.

Overcoming Anger

Iâ€™ve shared many stories about Kyleâ€™s anger because itâ€™s been our biggest struggle â€” and the very reason I started writing books about big feelings. Emotions rise and fall, but Iâ€™m incredibly proud of how far weâ€™ve come.

A few weeks ago, I asked Kyle to do something he didnâ€™t want to do. I could feel the anger building. His dad chimed in â€” which I knew would only make things harder.

Me: â€œTake deep breaths. I know youâ€™re upset, but donâ€™t let anger control you.â€

Kyle: â€œI canâ€™t! Itâ€™s too strong!â€

Me: â€œYouâ€™re stronger than your anger. You know what to do.â€

Things were about to escalate when he suddenly said:

â€œMom! Help! Get me a pen and paper!â€

So I did.

Finding His Own Way

As he wrote, I watched the anger slowly fade. He filled three pages before finally calming down.

What Helps When Iâ€™m Angry (written by Kyle)
1. Dadâ€™s voice sometimes makes me more angry.
2. When someone talks to me, I get more angry.
3. Be more gentle with me.
4. Blow on me like the Big Bad Wolf or Mr. Wolf.
5. Sing or play a song.
6. Punch beds.
7. Run crazy like Sonic.
8. Use pain â€” danger âœ— do not use.
9. Annoy me a bit â€” danger âœ— do not use.
10. Draw.
11. Rip paper.
12. Kiss me.
13. Making me calm down makes it harder for me to calm down.

Reading this felt like being handed a map into his inner world.

I felt such pride watching him put his feelings into words. He remembered the tools weâ€™d talked about over the years â€” and even discovered new ones on his own.

It felt like a quiet reassurance: Youâ€™re doing okay.

Gentle parenting isnâ€™t perfect. I still talk too much. I still tell him to calm down when I shouldnâ€™t. But moments like this remind me that the work matters.

Iâ€™ve kept those pages safe. Maybe Iâ€™ll laminate them and bring them out the next time emotions run high. Weâ€™ve gone two months without a major episode â€” not a guarantee, but a gift.

Thanks for being here and walking this journey with us.

What to do when your child says the words that break your heart

â€œDO IT.â€

â€œItâ€™s normal to feel angry,â€ I told him. â€œBut staying angry for too long can hurt your heart and make you feel weak. Anyone can be angry, but not everyone can overcome it. Learning to let go of anger makes you stronger. Weâ€™ve talked about different ways to do that â€” now you need to try them and find what works for you.â€

Iâ€™m learning to remind myself that my childâ€™s behavior is not always a reflection of my parenting. What matters more is how I respond.

items.content_html:
A gentle way to help children talk about nightmares, process fear, and feel safe again

A few months ago, my son woke up from a nightmare so intense that he couldnâ€™t explain it right away. Like many parents, my first instinct was to reassure himâ€”to remind him that it wasnâ€™t real, that he was safe, and that it was only a dream. But as the days passed and pieces of the dream slowly surfaced, I realized that what he needed most wasnâ€™t for the fear to be dismissed, but for it to be gently understood.

One night, as I was tucking him in, he looked at me and asked,

â€œDo you remember the scary dream I had?â€

â€œThe one with the wizard?â€ I asked.

He nodded. â€œIt was really scaryâ€¦â€

I gently asked, â€œDo you want to talk about it â€” and maybe try to make it a little less scary?â€

His eyes lit up. â€œOkay! What if the wizard was like Magic Koopa from Mario?â€

We laughed. We made the wizard dance. We made him silly. For a moment, the fear loosened its grip.

Then Kyle grew quiet again.

â€œThereâ€™s more I didnâ€™t tell you, Momâ€¦ because it was too scary.â€

He told me about an old man trapped inside a helmet. A duck. Pins and needles. And how the duck died.

â€œThat is a very sad dream,â€ I said. â€œDo you want to try changing it â€” just a little â€” so it doesnâ€™t feel so scary anymore?â€

He nodded.

So together, we changed the story.

The wizard became a good wizard. The needles became magic needles that stopped the pain. The duck was old and tired, and ready to rest.

The duckâ€™s family was waiting for him. The old man was sad â€” but he understood. And the duck died peacefully, surrounded by love.

When we finished, Kyle looked at me and said,

â€œThatâ€™s a nice story, Mom.â€

â€œDo you feel better now?â€ I asked.

â€œYes. Thanks, Mommy.â€

We hugged for a long time. Just before drifting off to sleep, he lifted his head one last time.

â€œMomâ€¦ did you enjoy talking about my dream and making it nicer?â€

â€œYes,â€ I said. â€œVery much.â€

This happened during a season of online learningâ€”I found myself walking a familiar line between encouragement and pressure.

â€œI know you can do it,â€ I said. â€œYouâ€™ve done this many times before and gotten the right answer. I think you just donâ€™t want to try.â€

Yesterday, I was busy and didnâ€™t notice right away that Kyle had been lying face-down on the couch for quite some time. Every time I asked him to come eat, he answered with a protesting grunt and hugged his furry dinosaur even tighter.

â€œWhatâ€™s wrong, Kyle? What happened?â€
grunt

I could hear him crying, so instead of pushing him to talk, I tried something that often works for usâ€”distraction first, conversation later.

items.content_html:
Do you talk to children about big, complicated topicsâ€”things like truth, fairness, leadership, and right versus wrong?

Growing up, those conversations rarely happened in my home. Adults talked; children listenedâ€”or were told they were â€œtoo youngâ€ to understand.

I remember how disempowering that felt. So when Kyle started getting curious about adult conversations, I decided to try something different.

Instead of shutting him out, I began explaining complex ideas in ways he could understandâ€”not to tell him what to think, but to help him learn how to think.

Â 

Truth vs. Opinion

One evening, we talked about the difference between facts and opinions.

Facts are things we can prove with evidence. Opinions are how we feel about those facts.

Kyle immediately jumped in:

â€œLikeâ€”fun fact: dinosaurs existed!â€

Exactly.

But saying someone is cute, funny, or scary? Those are opinions â€” and different people can feel differently.

Understanding that difference helps kids make sense of the world, especially in a time when they hear so many voices and ideas.

Fairness, Courage, and Doing Whatâ€™s Right

We also talked about people who stand up for what is right, even when itâ€™s difficult or dangerous.

I explained that some adults choose honesty and courage â€” telling the truth, protecting others, and standing up to bullies â€” even when it would be easier to stay quiet.

Kyle listened carefully, then said:

â€œSoâ€¦ being brave means doing good, even when itâ€™s hard?â€

Yes. Exactly.

Respect, Equality, and Kindness

That naturally led to a conversation about respect â€” being mindful of our words, our actions, and how they affect others.

We talked about being gentle with people who may be smaller, younger, or more vulnerable. About using strength to protect, not to harm.

And about kindness â€” especially when weâ€™re feeling silly, angry, or frustrated.

He thought about it quietly, then promised:

Our children are growing up in a complex world. Starting these conversations early helps them navigate it with confidence and compassion.

Believe there is good in the world. Be the good.

Moments of weakness are part of parenting.

The other day, we shared one of our proud moments of strength. Today, I want to share a moment of weakness.

Life isnâ€™t perfect. We all make mistakes. And sometimes, thatâ€™s exactly how growth begins.

July 13, 2021

I thought I finally had things figured out: as long as I stayed calm when Kyle had a tantrum, it wouldnâ€™t escalate into full-blown rage.

When he started kindergarten online classes at â€œbig school,â€ I assumed it would be easy. He had adjusted well to online preschool, so I expected more of the same.

I was wrong.

Sitting through two and a half hours of structured learning was hardâ€”especially when he already knew most of the lessons. The Zoom chat box was a constant distraction. The rocking chair banged against the floor, scratching our parquet tiles and slowly wearing down my patience.

One day, everything piled up.

I was stressed about meals, about training a new cook, about the house. I felt watched and judged for things that didnâ€™t really matterâ€”but felt heavy all the same.

When Kyle minimized the Zoom window to Google things during class, I snapped.

He came over to me, growling, trying to release his frustration. He hugged meâ€”but I was still upset.

Then, in a split second, he lashed out and hit me in the eye.

It hurt. I screamed. And in shock, I reacted in a way I never thought I would.

I spanked him.

Almost immediately, the contradiction hit me: How does hitting a child teach them not to hit?

But in that moment, all I wanted was for him to understand how much it hurtâ€”so he wouldnâ€™t do it again.

Afterward, I sat alone, angry and ashamed, wondering if everything I believed about positive parenting had been naive.

Later, Kyle came to me. He apologized. We talked. We processed what happenedâ€”like we usually do.

Still, the self-doubt lingered.

Eventually, I realized something important: the problem wasnâ€™t my parenting philosophy. It was my internal pressureâ€”my expectations, my unresolved beliefs, and the quiet fear of being judged.

Children arenâ€™t meant to sit still for long hours. Restlessness isnâ€™t misbehavior. Itâ€™s biology.

What I was really struggling with was the belief that my childâ€™s behavior was a reflection of my worth as a parent.

What an unbearable burden to place on a five-year-old.

There is no room for shame in parenting. And there is value in all forms of workâ€”whether seen or unseen.

We are enough simply by being.

Once I let go of that pressure, things softened. Kyle still has outburstsâ€”but theyâ€™re calmer now, and easier to move through.

Parenting is a roller coaster. There will be more moments of weakness. But those moments, if we let them, can lead us toward growthâ€”and toward strength.
